April 21, 1985: Fiction
FAMILY ALBUM, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $16.95.) A married couple with five
children cope with the crises of contemporary America.
IF TOMORROW COMES, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $17.95.) A young woman
destroys the crime lords who got her an undeserved prison term.
INSIDE, OUTSIDE, by Herman Wouk. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) A traditionalist Jew's
quest for identity in contemporary America.
THINNER, by Richard Bachman. (NAL Books,  $12.95.)In this pseudonymous
novel by Stephen King, a young lawyer finds his body mysteriously wasting away.
THE LONELY SILVER RAIN, by John D. MacDonald. (Knopf, $15.95.) A yacht's
disappearance, a debutante's murder and other puzzles Travis McGee must solve
to save his life.
PROOF, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $16.95.) A young wine merchant gets caught
in a scam involving murder and vengeance.
THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Naval Institute Press,
$14.95.) A Lithuanian submarine driver defects to the United States with the
Soviet Union's most advanced nuclear secrets.
GLITZ, by Elmore Leonard. (Arbor House, $14.95.) The escapades, romantic and
melodramatic, of a cop on the lam after a murder in Miami.
SEE YOU LATER ALLIGATOR, by William F. Buckley Jr. (Doubleday, $15.95.)
John F. Kennedy sends Blackford Oakes to Havana on the eve of the missile
crisis.
HOTEL DU LAC, by Anita Brookner. (Pantheon, $13.95.) A successful novelist
learns that a solitary life is still worth living.
MINDBEND, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $15.95.) A drug company gains control of
the medical profession.
QUEENIE, by Michael Korda. (Linden Press/  Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The
glittery career of Dawn Avalon, whose life was not unlike that of the late Merle
Oberon.
THE FINISHING SCHOOL, by Gail Godwin.(Viking, $16.95.) A young girl's
relationship with an older woman leads to her mentor's downfall.
CHAPTERHOUSE: DUNE, by Frank Herbert. (Putnam, $17.95.) A new world rises
from the Old Empire's ashes in this volume of the ''Dune'' series.
THE TALISMAN, by Stephen King and Peter Straub. (Viking, $18.95.) Two parallel
April 21, 1985
Non-Fiction
IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca with William Novak. (Bantam,
$19.95.) The rise of the automobile executive from immigrants' son to top jobs at
Ford and Chrysler.
BREAKING WITH MOSCOW, by Arkady N. Shevchenko. (Knopf, $18.95.) The
autobiography of the highest-ranking Soviet official ever to defect.
LOVING EACH OTHER, by Leo Buscaglia.  (Slack/Holt, Rinehart & Winston,
$13.95.) Suggestions for ''setting our priorities right in order to enjoy life to the
fullest.''
SMART WOMEN, FOOLISH CHOICES, by Connell Cowan and Melvyn Kinder.
(Clarkson N. Potter, $13.95.) Two psychologists analyze the successes and
failures of women in looking for good men.
THE COURAGE TO CHANGE, by Dennis Wholey. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.)
Conversations with two dozen men and women, many of them celebrities, about
their problems with alcoholism.
CITIZEN HUGHES, by Michael Drosnin. (Holt, Rinehart & Winston, $18.95.)
Howard Hughes's attempts to control the Government during his last years of life.
THE BRIDGE ACROSS FOREVER, by Richard Bach. (Morrow, $16.95.) The
author of ''Jonathan Livingston Seagull'' tells of his search for love.
''SURELY YOU'RE JOKING, MR. FEYNMANN,'' by Richard P. Feynmann.
(Norton, $15.95.) A Nobel laureate in physics recounts his curious misadventures
inside and outside his profession.
A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse
and drawings.
MOSES THE KITTEN, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $9.95.) A waif kitten is
adopted by a pig; illustrated.
THE SOONG DYNASTY, by Sterling Seagrave. (Harper & Row, $22.50.) The
tangled lives of the six children of Charlie Soong, who shaped much of China's
modern history.
SON OF THE MORNING STAR, by Evan S. Connell. (North Point, $20.) A
biography of Custer that is also a history of the Plains Indian wars.
THE LIVING PLANET, by David Attenborough. (Little, Brown, $25.) The land and
waters of our earth and the creatures that call them home.
THE BLOOD OF ABRAHAM, by Jimmy Carter. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) The
problems of the Middle East and what can be done about them, as seen by the
